query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several methods: Fallowing between production cycles has been associated with lower sea lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in Scotland, though one Australian study found no difference in Amoebic Gill Disease (AGD) mortality (1026). Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents showed mixed results: corkwing and goldsinny wrasse matched chemical treatments in controlling lice in one controlled study, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective in a replicated, controlled study (738). Freshwater bathing for AGD produced mixed outcomes in Australia: one study found reduced amoebae on gills lasting up to 10 days, while a replicated, controlled study found no difference from untreated fish (739). Altering lighting reduced lice loads in a replicated, controlled Norway study, with lower lice under low-intensity artificial or natural light and higher lice under more intense artificial light (741). Dietary approaches including probiotics, plant-based protein inclusion, and immunostimulants showed benefits: in Scotland, probiotics increased survival after bacterial challenges; in Norway, a diet with 28% plant protein reduced lice infection by 28% and adding beta-glucans reduced lice a further 28%; mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function and prevented soybean-induced enteritis (732). Vaccinations increased survival against multiple pathogens in controlled studies from Iceland, Norway, Australia, and Canada, including Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia (733). Selective breeding for resistance improved survival under infectious pancreatic necrosis exposure in a replicated, controlled Norway study (735).

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary: In Norway, replicated controlled studies on bacterial protein reported similar growth rates to 100% fish meal when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced, lower growth at 50% replacement, and higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control or a 4.5% bacterial protein diet [918]. For plant-based proteins, studies including those from Norway reported decreased growth rates with plant-protein inclusion, while other Norwegian studies reported similar growth rates compared to fish meal; additional Norwegian evidence reported both reduced and similar final body weights relative to fish meal diets [924].

  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Vaccinations increased survival rates in multiple controlled studies after exposure to Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri (Iceland, Norway), marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease (Australia, Canada), and infectious salmon anaemia (Norway) [733]. Aerobic training increased survival following exposure to infectious pancreatic necrosis in a randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway, with interval training more effective than continuous training [740]. Breeding for resistance traits increased survival in salmon families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to low-resistance families in a replicated, controlled study in Norway [735].

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Across replicated and controlled studies in Norway and Scotland, inclusion of plant-based proteins in salmon feeds has been associated with: decreased growth rates in several studies, though some studies reported similar growth to fish meal-based diets [924]; reduced final body weights in multiple studies, while other studies found no difference from fish meal-based diets [924]; mixed effects on feed efficiency, with some studies showing lower efficiency, one showing higher efficiency, and others showing no difference compared to fish meal diets [924]; mixed results for digestibility, with some studies finding lower digestibility of feed components and others reporting similar digestibility to fish meal diets [924]; no detected effects on survival rates or appetite in two studies [924]; altered distal intestinal morphology in two studies [924]; and mixed effects on fish condition, with one study reporting increased condition and two reporting reduced condition on plant-based protein diets [924].

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several non-chemical approaches: using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents, with mixed outcomes—one controlled study found corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while another replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse ineffective at preventing outbreaks [738]. Altering lighting, with a replicated, controlled study in Norway reporting lower lice numbers under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting, and higher lice numbers under more intense artificial light [741]. Implementing fallowing, with a study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system, though another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease when fallowing was used [1026].

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: Two replicated studies in Norway reported similar final weight gain between Atlantic salmon fed fishmeal or krill meal; when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to fishmeal than with whole krill, and feed conversion ratios were similar between fishmeal and krill meal [916]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between salmon fed the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and a fishmeal control [920]. One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins [922].

query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: In Norway, three controlled, replicated (two randomised) studies found no difference in growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified (GM) or non-GM soybeans, and one randomised, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology between fish fed GM vs non-GM soybean diets [928]. For plant-based protein sources, studies from Norway reported mixed growth outcomes: some studies found decreased growth rates with plant-based proteins, while other studies found similar growth rates to fish meal diets [924]. Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights with plant-based protein diets, while two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights to fish meal [924]. In Norway, two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) found lowered feeding efficiency with plant-based protein diets, whereas one replicated study found increased feeding efficiency [924]. Two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway reported similar digestibility between plant and fish meal diets [924]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway using the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica reported no differences in weight compared to a fishmeal control [920].

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary: Replicated and controlled studies report no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight for several options: dietary supplementation with phytase and phosphate resulted in no difference in weight gain compared to no supplementation, with one study finding greater final weights with phytase, and taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain [930]. Two replicated studies found similar final weight gain when fish meal was replaced with a krill meal substitute, with de-shelled krill producing growth rates closer to fish meal than whole krill [916]. For plant-based proteins, multiple replicated/controlled studies reported similar growth rates and similar final body weights to fish meal diets, although other studies reported reductions [924]. For bacterial protein, two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced, while another study reported higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein; however, a 50% replacement reduced growth [918].

query: What is the evidence that integrated aquaculture systems or constructing artificial reefs can mitigate the environmental impacts of salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies on artificial reefs near aquaculture sites reported no detectable differences compared to sites without aquaculture: one Mediterranean study found similar invertebrate community composition on an artificial reef under aquaculture cages versus reefs away from cages, and one Gulf of Aqaba study found similar invertebrate biomass on an artificial reef at an aquaculture site versus a site without cages [2260]. For proposed mitigation approaches related to integrated aquaculture systems and biofiltration, evidence gaps were identified: no studies were found evaluating the effects of using species from multiple trophic levels in aquaculture systems [2195], locating artificial reefs near aquaculture to act explicitly as biofilters [2196], locating aquaculture systems in vegetated areas [2189], or establishing aquaculture specifically to extract nutrients from run-offs [2200].

query: How do physical interventions like aerobic training and altering cage size affect the health and survival of farmed Atlantic salmon?

query: What are the observed effects on salmon growth and flesh quality when replacing fish oil with plant-based or other animal-based oils in their diet?
relevant_summary: Across replicated studies in Norway and Scotland, replacing fish oil with vegetable (plant-based) oils produced: (1) growth outcomes that were similar between fish oil and vegetable oil diets in three studies, with one study reporting higher growth on vegetable oil, and one replicated, controlled study showing growth was both lower and higher on vegetable oil depending on family genetics [926]; (2) similar average final body weights between fish fed fish oil and vegetable oil diets in two studies [926]; (3) flesh fatty acid profiles that reflected the dietary oil source in multiple studies [926]; (4) lower concentrations of dioxins and polychlorinated biphenyls in flesh when fish were fed vegetable oil-based diets compared to fish oil diets in a replicated, controlled study [926]; (5) similar gaping, texture, and liquid-holding capacity in fresh, frozen, and smoked flesh between diets, while pigment concentration was lower with vegetable oil diets [926]; (6) higher liver lipid and lower plasma lipoprotein in salmon fed vegetable oil diets compared to fish oil diets in one replicated study [926]; and (7) one replicated, controlled study reporting high levels of n-3 highly unsaturated fatty acids compared to diets containing rapeseed oil [926]. No specific action documents were found detailing effects of replacing fish oil with other animal-based oils beyond these plant-based oil findings.

query: What is the evidence regarding the effect of using genetically modified ingredients or dietary supplements on the growth of Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: Three controlled, replicated (two randomised) studies in Norway found no difference in growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified or non‑genetically modified soybeans [928]. A controlled, replicated study in Australia found no difference in weight gain with dietary supplementation of phytase and phosphate, while another controlled, replicated study in Australia reported greater final weights in fish fed phytase‑supplemented diets compared to no supplement [930]. A controlled, replicated study in Norway found no difference in weight gain with taurine supplementation compared to no supplementation [930].

query: What is the evidence from European studies for using vaccinations or probiotics to improve the survival rates of farmed Atlantic salmon?
relevant_summary: Two controlled studies in Europe (Iceland and Norway) found higher survival in vaccinated Atlantic salmon after exposure to Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively [733]. Two additional controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia [733]. One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28‑day period compared with controls [732].

query: What actions are available to manage the waste products, such as excess nutrients and sludge, from salmon aquaculture operations?
relevant_summary:
- Integrated aquaculture systems co-culturing extractive species alongside salmon farms can assimilate wastes: studies reported blue mussels absorbing waste from a salmon farm, greater scallop growth next to fish farms, and enhanced algal growth adjacent to fish farms; one study found no evidence that oysters and mussels fed on fish farm waste (932). 
- Fallowing salmon cages to reduce pollution has been trialed; sediment community structure under Atlantic salmon cages became more similar to non‑impacted sites over two fallowing cycles (1027). 
- Establishing aquaculture specifically to extract nutrients from run‑offs is identified as an action, though the evidence base for effects on marine or freshwater mammals has not been established (2883, 3587). 
- Using species from more than one trophic level in aquaculture (e.g., IMTA approaches) is identified as an action, though effects on subtidal benthic invertebrates have not yet been evaluated (2195). 
- Other bioremediation methods in aquaculture are identified as potential actions, but effects on subtidal benthic invertebrates have not yet been evaluated (2197). 
- Modifying aquaculture practices in the watershed to reduce pollution is listed as an action, but no studies were found evaluating effects on marsh or swamp vegetation (3172).

query: What is the evidence from Australian studies on the effectiveness of different husbandry practices for managing Amoebic Gill Disease in farmed salmon?
relevant_summary: Australian studies report mixed effects of freshwater bathing on amoebic gill disease: one study found reduced numbers of amoebae on salmon gills persisting for up to 10 days after bathing, while one replicated, controlled study found similar levels of amoebae in treated and untreated salmon [739]. A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon kept in larger cages compared to smaller cages [742]. One study in Australia found no difference in mortality from amoebic gill disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used [1026].

query: Beyond growth rates, what other biological effects have been observed in salmon fed diets with krill or plant-based proteins instead of fish meal?
relevant_summary: Plant-based proteins: feeding efficiency was lowered in two replicated, controlled studies, increased in one replicated study, and similar in two replicated studies (ID: 924). Digestibility of feed components was lower in two replicated, controlled studies, with similar digestibility reported in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies (ID: 924). Survival rates and appetite were not affected in two studies (ID: 924). Morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies (ID: 924). Condition increased in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but was reduced in two other replicated studies (ID: 924). Krill meal: feed conversion ratios were similar to fish meal (ID: 916). In salmon fed fish meal and krill meal, the number of aerobic bacteria in the hindgut was higher and the composition of the bacterial flora was different (ID: 916).

query: What factors influence the success of non-pesticide methods for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence indicates that outcomes depend on the specific method and implementation: the effectiveness of cleaner wrasse varies by species, with one controlled study finding corkwing and goldsinny wrasse as effective as chemical treatments while another found rockcook wrasse ineffective at preventing outbreaks [738]. Light regime matters, with lower lice counts under natural or low‑intensity artificial light, and higher counts as artificial light intensity increases [741]. Farm management through fallowing has been associated with lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in at least one study [1026]. Nutritional and immunostimulant strategies can reduce lice infection levels, including a diet with 28% plant-based protein and additional reductions when beta‑glucans are added, compared with controls [732].

query: In Norway, how do different plant-based feed alternatives, such as vegetable oils versus plant proteins, affect salmon growth and body composition?
relevant_summary: Across studies that included Norway, plant-protein diets sometimes reduced growth rates compared to fish meal, though some studies reported similar growth rates (924). Reduced final body weights were reported in replicated, controlled studies conducted in Norway and Scotland, while two Norwegian studies found similar final weights between plant-protein and fish-meal diets (924). In Norway, feeding efficiency responses to plant proteins were mixed, with two replicated, controlled studies showing lower efficiency and one replicated study showing higher efficiency compared to fish-meal diets; some other studies reported similar efficiency (924). For vegetable oils in Norway, multiple replicated studies found growth rates similar to fish-oil diets, one study found higher growth on vegetable oils, and one controlled study showed family-dependent higher or lower growth on vegetable oils (926). Norwegian studies reported similar average final body weights between fish-oil and vegetable-oil diets (926). Body composition responses with vegetable oils included salmon flesh fatty-acid profiles reflecting dietary oil source in Norway and Scotland, higher liver lipid and lower plasma lipoprotein on vegetable-oil diets in a Norwegian study, and lower flesh pigment concentration with vegetable oils alongside similar gaping, texture, and liquid-holding capacity in Norwegian product-quality tests (926).

query: What are the documented effects, both positive and negative, of replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: Across studies, replacing fish meal with plant-based proteins in Atlantic salmon diets was associated with decreased growth rates in six studies, while three studies found similar growth to fish meal diets (924). Four studies reported reduced final body weight with plant-based protein diets, whereas two found similar final body weight to fish meal diets (924). Feeding efficiency was lowered in two studies, increased in one, and similar in two others when using plant-based proteins (924). Digestibility of feed components was lower in two studies with plant proteins, but similar in two other studies (924). Two studies reported no effect on survival or appetite (924). Distal intestine morphology was altered in two studies with plant-based proteins (924). Condition increased in one study but was reduced in two others with plant-based protein diets (924). Additionally, two replicated studies found similar final weights across diets containing low, medium, or high levels of fish meal (915).

query: What does the evidence say about using probiotics, immunostimulants, or specific training to improve salmon survival against diseases?
relevant_summary: A replicated study in Scotland reported increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four disease-causing bacteria over 28 days compared with controls (732). A replicated, controlled study in Norway found salmon fed a diet with 28% plant-based protein had 28% fewer lice infections than controls, and adding beta-glucans decreased lice infection levels by a further 28%; mannan oligosaccharides also improved gut function by preventing soybean-induced enteritis (732). A randomized, replicated, controlled study in Norway found salmon that underwent aerobic training had higher survival when exposed to infectious pancreatic necrosis, with interval training more effective than continuous training (740).
